title: Salih Delalić
text:
Salih Delalić (21 July 1948 – 26 October 2002) was a Bosnian professional <a href="Football%20player">footballer</a>, <a href="engineer">engineer</a> and <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Business%20administration">administrator</a>.
Club career.
He started his professional career with his hometown side <a href="NK%20Slaven%20%C5%BDivinice">Slaven Živinice</a> in 1966, before transferring to <a href="FK%20Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a> one year later. Delalić was a member of the first Sarajevo championship winning generation that clinched the <a href="Yugoslav%20First%20League">Yugoslav First League</a> title in the <a href="1966%E2%80%9367%20Yugoslav%20First%20League">1966–67</a> season and that was narrowly defeated by <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> in the second round of the <a href="1967%E2%80%9368%20European%20Cup">1967–68 European Cup</a>. A 0–0 draw in the first leg at the <a href="Ko%C5%A1evo%20City%20Stadium">Koševo City Stadium</a> was followed by a 2–1 defeat in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>, yet Delalić made history by scoring Sarajevo's goal that night, becoming the first player from the former <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> to score at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a>.
Personal life.
After retiring from professional football, he enjoyed a successful career as an <a href="engineer">engineer</a>. In 2001, Delalić was elected as the 27th President of the Assembly of his former club Sarajevo, a position he held on to until his sudden and unexpected death on 26 October 2002.
Death.
Delalić died unexpectedly in his hometown of <a href="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>, <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> on 26 October 2002, at the age of 54.
Honours.
Player.
Sarajevo
